Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story:
As a grandmother, I always look forward to the family holiday. It’s the one time of year when my children and grandchildren gather, laughter echoing through the house, stories shared over tea. My daughter called this morning, reminding me to wear the new dress she bought for me—a bright, sleeveless gown she thought would make me look “modern” in the family photos. She sounded so excited, and I didn’t want to disappoint her.

But as a Muslim, I feel a deep responsibility to dress modestly, especially in public and around men who aren’t family. This afternoon, my office is hosting a function with colleagues from every department, men and women alike. The invitation says “dress smart, be festive,” and I know my daughter expects me to wear her gift. Yet, I can’t ignore the discomfort that rises in me at the thought of wearing something that doesn’t align with my beliefs.

I stand in front of my closet, the new dress hanging beside my usual long-sleeved abaya. My phone buzzes with a message from my granddaughter, “Can’t wait to see you, Nana!” My heart aches as I weigh the expectations of my family against my faith, unsure which path to take.
